articles.headline: F.D.A. Revokes Approval of Avastin for Use as Breast Cancer Drug
articles.snippet: The agency said the drug “has not been shown to be safe and effective” for breast cancer patients, but would remain available for treating other types of cancer.
articles.abstract: The agency said the drug “has not been shown to be safe and effective” for breast cancer patients, but would remain available for treating other types of cancer.
articles.lead_paragraph: The commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration on Friday revoked the approval of the drug Avastin as a treatment for breast cancer, ruling on an emotional issue that pitted the hopes of some desperate patients against the statistics of clinical trials.

articles.headline: 5 Ways to Think About Nuisance Fees
articles.snippet: Ron Lieber enlisted the help of consumers and wrote a new set of rules on how to deal with Bank of America’s debit card fee and the copycats in other industries.
articles.abstract: Ron Lieber enlisted the help of consumers and wrote a new set of rules on how to deal with Bank of America’s debit card fee and the copycats in other industries.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you have any doubt about the impact of the Bank of America debit card fee episode, consider a couple of things.

articles.headline: A Retailer’s Base Camp in Manhattan
articles.snippet: REI, an outdoor-equipment retailer, is preparing to open its first store in New York by providing employees training in the wilds of Manhattan.
articles.abstract: REI, an outdoor-equipment retailer, is preparing to open its first store in New York by providing employees training in the wilds of Manhattan.
articles.lead_paragraph: Outdoor adventurers keep lists of life’s places to explore: Everest, El Capitan, the Middle Fork of the Salmon. On one unseasonably warm November day, Dyckman Street and 10th Avenue in Manhattan became one such destination, at least for nine newcomers to New York City.

articles.headline: An Uprising With Plenty of Potential
articles.snippet: Both critics and supporters of Occupy Wall Street suggest that the movement’s influence could last decades, and that it might even evolve into a more potent force.
articles.abstract: Both critics and supporters of Occupy Wall Street suggest that the movement’s influence could last decades, and that it might even evolve into a more potent force.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the wake of this week’s eviction of protesters from Zuccotti Park in New York and other urban campgrounds around the country, it’s tempting to dismiss the Occupy Wall Street movement as little more than a short-lived media phenomenon. The issues that spawned the movement — income inequality, money in politics and Wall Street’s influence — were being drowned out by debates over personal hygiene, noise and crime.

articles.headline: Europe Fears a Credit Squeeze as Investors Sell Bond Holdings
articles.snippet: Financial institutions around the world are getting rid of holdings in European government debt and spurning new bond issues, raising fear of a credit crisis.
articles.abstract: Financial institutions around the world are getting rid of holdings in European government debt and spurning new bond issues, raising fear of a credit crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nervous investors around the globe are accelerating their exit from the debt of European governments and banks, increasing the risk of a credit squeeze that could set off a downward spiral.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Eric Dash

articles.headline: As Deadline Nears, Deficit Panel Is Still at Deep Impasse
articles.snippet: Pessimism mounted among members of a Congressional panel on deficit reduction about their ability to strike a deal by Monday and avert a high-profile failure.
articles.abstract: Pessimism mounted among members of a Congressional panel on deficit reduction about their ability to strike a deal by Monday and avert a high-profile failure.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just 72 hours before a deadline to present Congress with a plan to cut $1.2 trillion from the nation’s deficit, members of a joint Congressional committee remained at a deep impasse on Friday after Democrats rejected a new Republican proposal devised with the help of Speaker John A. Boehner.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Robert Pear

articles.headline: Vilifying Rival, Wall St. Rallies for Senate Ally
articles.snippet: Senator Scott P. Brown of Massachusetts, a leading fund-raiser in the financial industry, is expected to face Elizabeth Warren, a strong proponent of regulation, next year.
articles.abstract: Senator Scott P. Brown of Massachusetts, a leading fund-raiser in the financial industry, is expected to face Elizabeth Warren, a strong proponent of regulation, next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: The warning has ricocheted around the financial world in recent weeks, in conversations at Midtown restaurants and Washington fund-raisers, carrying urgent appeals for money from financial executives around the Northeast: The battle to re-elect Senator Scott P. Brown, the Republican from Massachusetts, just got a little more interesting.

articles.headline: Tax Pledge May Scuttle a Deal on Deficit
articles.snippet: Congressional Republicans have vowed not to raise taxes, but combinations of tax increases and spending cuts are a time-honored way to cut the deficit.
articles.abstract: Congressional Republicans have vowed not to raise taxes, but combinations of tax increases and spending cuts are a time-honored way to cut the deficit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three-quarters of Americans — including more than half of Republicans — say they believe that any deficit reduction plan should include tax increases, according to a recent New York Times/CBS poll. But Congressional Republicans are not so sure.

articles.headline: Older, Suburban and Struggling, ‘Near Poor’ Startle the Census
articles.snippet: A new Census Bureau measure denotes households pulled out of poverty by benefits or closer to it by certain expenses, and a count suggests they are far more numerous than previously understood.
articles.abstract: A new Census Bureau measure denotes households pulled out of poverty by benefits or closer to it by certain expenses, and a count suggests they are far more numerous than previously understood.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — They drive cars, but seldom new ones. They earn paychecks, but not big ones. Many own homes. Most pay taxes. Half are married, and nearly half live in the suburbs. None are poor, but many describe themselves as barely scraping by.
articles.byline: By Jason DeParle, Robert Gebeloff and Sabrina Tavernise

articles.headline: Violent Protests in Egypt Pit Thousands Against Police
articles.snippet: An outpouring on the streets of Cairo on Saturday was the strongest rebuke yet against attempts by Egypt’s military to grant itself permanent governmental powers.
articles.abstract: An outpouring on the streets of Cairo on Saturday was the strongest rebuke yet against attempts by Egypt’s military to grant itself permanent governmental powers.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A police action to roust a few hundred protesters out of Tahrir Square on Saturday instead drew thousands of people from across Egyptian society into the streets, where they battled riot police officers for hours in the most violent manifestation yet of growing anger at the military-led interim government.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Liam Stack

articles.headline: Redefining the Union Boss
articles.snippet: In this “We are the 99 percent” moment, when corporate profits are up and wages flat, a handful of women are challenging the old, mostly male world of union bosses.
articles.abstract: In this “We are the 99 percent” moment, when corporate profits are up and wages flat, a handful of women are challenging the old, mostly male world of union bosses.
articles.lead_paragraph: NOT long ago, truckers pulled off highways across America and tuned in to someone whose CB handle was “Troublemaker.”

articles.headline: Scare Tactics in Greece
articles.snippet: Behind the scenes, there appears to be some arm-twisting to persuade holders of Greek bonds to accept a restructuring deal.
articles.abstract: Behind the scenes, there appears to be some arm-twisting to persuade holders of Greek bonds to accept a restructuring deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: AS the debt mess in Europe deepens, bankers are pressing Greece’s bond holders to swallow big losses.

articles.headline: Mobile Deals Set to Lure Shoppers Stuck in Line
articles.snippet: Aggressive promotions by online merchants are creating a frenzy among traditional retailers, who count the Friday after Thanksgiving as the busiest shopping day of the year.
articles.abstract: Aggressive promotions by online merchants are creating a frenzy among traditional retailers, who count the Friday after Thanksgiving as the busiest shopping day of the year.
articles.lead_paragraph: As retailers battle to draw customers into their stores on Black Friday, online merchants are plotting a cunning ambush — offering an arsenal of mobile-only deals intended to pick off shoppers as they wait in line.

articles.headline: Headphones With Swagger (and Lots of Bass)
articles.snippet: The rap impresario Dr. Dre is the celebrity behind Beats, a successful line of expensive headphones that have become a fashion accessory.
articles.abstract: The rap impresario Dr. Dre is the celebrity behind Beats, a successful line of expensive headphones that have become a fashion accessory.
articles.lead_paragraph: DR. DRE, the sonic architect of gangsta rap, is surrounded by a gaggle of slack-jawed journalists and micro-skirted cocktail waitresses. It’s not quite 5 in the afternoon, and already the scene is a testosterone fantasy of swaggering grooves and flowing vodka.

articles.headline: Sectarian Strife in City Bodes Ill for All of Syria
articles.snippet: In the ethnically diverse city of Homs, violence between Alawite and Sunni is rife, offering a chilling vision of Syria’s possible future.
articles.abstract: In the ethnically diverse city of Homs, violence between Alawite and Sunni is rife, offering a chilling vision of Syria’s possible future.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A harrowing sectarian war has spread across the Syrian city of Homs this month, with supporters and opponents of the government blamed for beheadings, rival gangs carrying out tit-for-tat kidnappings, minorities fleeing for their native villages, and taxi drivers too fearful of drive-by shootings to ply the streets.

articles.headline: What They Don’t Teach Law Students: Lawyering
articles.snippet: Law schools have long emphasized the theoretical over the useful, leaving law firms fairly resigned to training their hires how to actually practice law.
articles.abstract: Law schools have long emphasized the theoretical over the useful, leaving law firms fairly resigned to training their hires how to actually practice law.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The lesson today — the ins and outs of closing a deal — seems lifted from Corporate Lawyering 101.

articles.headline: Costly Aircraft Suggests Cuts Won’t Be Easy
articles.snippet: The Osprey has survived after repeated safety problems during testing, years of delays, ballooning costs and tough questions about the aircraft’s utility.
articles.abstract: The Osprey has survived after repeated safety problems during testing, years of delays, ballooning costs and tough questions about the aircraft’s utility.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta shoved his head into a snug aviator helmet topped with goggles one September morning and swooped into Lower Manhattan on a V-22 Osprey, a $70 million aircraft that Marines use for battlefield assaults in Afghanistan.

articles.headline: Romney Shifts in Iowa, Playing to Win Quickly
articles.snippet: After cautiously calibrating expectations about his chances in a state full of social conservatives, Mitt Romney is now playing to win the Iowa caucuses.
articles.abstract: After cautiously calibrating expectations about his chances in a state full of social conservatives, Mitt Romney is now playing to win the Iowa caucuses.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — The answer to one of the great lingering questions about the Republican presidential race has suddenly turned up here along Ingersoll Avenue, where Mitt Romney’s Iowa campaign headquarters is opening for business.

articles.headline: Facing Calls to Give Up Power, Egypt’s Military Battles Crowds
articles.snippet: Egypt’s military rulers struggled to contain an explosion of protests demanding their ouster, as demonstrators again pushed security forces out of Tahrir Square and new clashes broke out elsewhere.
articles.abstract: Egypt’s military rulers struggled to contain an explosion of protests demanding their ouster, as demonstrators again pushed security forces out of Tahrir Square and new clashes broke out elsewhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s military rulers struggled Sunday to contain an explosion of protests demanding their ouster, as a growing crowd of demonstrators pushed security forces out of Tahrir Square for a second night in a row and new clashes broke out across the country.

articles.headline: Lawmakers Trade Blame as Deficit Talks Crumble
articles.snippet: With a bipartisan panel on the verge of failing to reach a compromise on a way to lower the federal deficit, the focus shifted to the automatic cuts that would go into effect in 2013.
articles.abstract: With a bipartisan panel on the verge of failing to reach a compromise on a way to lower the federal deficit, the focus shifted to the automatic cuts that would go into effect in 2013.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the hours ticking away toward a self-imposed deadline, Congressional leaders conceded Sunday that talks on a sweeping deficit agreement were near failure and braced for recriminations over their inability to reach a deal.

articles.headline: Stocks, So Far Resilient, Face a Week of Challenges
articles.snippet: The prospective failure of the deficit panel in Congress and bond auctions by fiscally shaky European governments could be a drag on markets.
articles.abstract: The prospective failure of the deficit panel in Congress and bond auctions by fiscally shaky European governments could be a drag on markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite one negative headline from Europe after another, the stock market in the United States has held up pretty well lately, rising 10 percent since the beginning of October. But that could change this week, amid mounting investor doubt about the ability of political leaders on both sides of the Atlantic to slash spending and control budget deficits.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Graham Bowley

articles.headline: For Their Children, Many E-Book Fans Insist on Paper
articles.snippet: Many parents say they want their children to be surrounded by print books, and to experience turning physical pages as they learn about shapes, colors and animals.
articles.abstract: Many parents say they want their children to be surrounded by print books, and to experience turning physical pages as they learn about shapes, colors and animals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Print books may be under siege from the rise of e-books, but they have a tenacious hold on a particular group: children and toddlers. Their parents are insisting this next generation of readers spend their early years with old-fashioned books.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: Trolling Overseas for TV Concepts to Mine
articles.snippet: Media companies have discovered that formats, or the concepts behind a reality TV or game show, travel well and are very cheap to make.
articles.abstract: Media companies have discovered that formats, or the concepts behind a reality TV or game show, travel well and are very cheap to make.
articles.lead_paragraph: American media companies may be cutting back on the domestic front, but they are shopping heavily overseas. The object of their desires? Reality shows like “Big Brother,” “Promzillas” and “Freaky Eaters.”

articles.headline: For a Movement, a Question: What Now?
articles.snippet: Without a physical anchor, a movement’s way forward is unclear. But its impact may have already been made.
articles.abstract: Without a physical anchor, a movement’s way forward is unclear. But its impact may have already been made.
articles.lead_paragraph: After last week’s dead-of-night operation in New York to break up the protest site in Zuccotti Park, and similar actions in other cities, it is inevitable that Occupy Wall Street will eventually become more of an idea than a place.

articles.headline: Balancing U.S. Policy on an Ally in Transition
articles.snippet: The latest clashes in Cairo are a reminder that the United States must balance support for democratic change, a desire for stability and wariness of Islamists in Egypt.
articles.abstract: The latest clashes in Cairo are a reminder that the United States must balance support for democratic change, a desire for stability and wariness of Islamists in Egypt.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the United States, the weekend clashes in Cairo crystallized the defining policy quandary of the Arab Spring: how to square contradictory American impulses that include support for democratic change, a desire for stability and wariness of Islamists who have become a potent political force.

articles.headline: Protest Puts Coverage in Spotlight
articles.snippet: Occupy Wall Street has become something of an ideological litmus test, spawning accusations of media bias from the left and the right.
articles.abstract: Occupy Wall Street has become something of an ideological litmus test, spawning accusations of media bias from the left and the right.
articles.lead_paragraph: As police officers cleared protesters last week from Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan, the birthplace of Occupy Wall Street, they made sure most reporters were kept blocks away, supposedly for their own protection.

articles.headline: Mixed Results as Google Enters Microsoft’s Turf
articles.snippet: Google has lured some small businesses away from Microsoft Office by offering similar features at lower cost. But big companies have been harder to land.
articles.abstract: Google has lured some small businesses away from Microsoft Office by offering similar features at lower cost. But big companies have been harder to land.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Michael O’Brien, vice president for information technology at Journal Communications, would prefer not to have the employees of the Milwaukee media company use Microsoft’s Office software any more.

articles.headline: Taking First-Class Coddling Above and Beyond
articles.snippet: Airlines have engaged in a global battle for the superwealthy, offering amenities on international flights once found only on corporate jets.
articles.abstract: Airlines have engaged in a global battle for the superwealthy, offering amenities on international flights once found only on corporate jets.
articles.lead_paragraph: The gap between first class and coach has never been so wide.

articles.headline: The Deficit Deal That Wasn’t: Hopes Are Dashed
articles.snippet: Not only could Democrats and Republicans not agree on a deficit deal, they could not even agree after it failed about what had gone wrong.
articles.abstract: Not only could Democrats and Republicans not agree on a deficit deal, they could not even agree after it failed about what had gone wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The one sliver of real hope came a week ago, in the darkened Capitol on the Sunday night after Veterans Day.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Robert Pear

articles.headline: Egypt’s Cabinet Offers to Resign as Protests Rage
articles.snippet: After three days of increasingly violent demonstrations, Egypt’s interim civilian government submitted its resignation to the country’s ruling military council.
articles.abstract: After three days of increasingly violent demonstrations, Egypt’s interim civilian government submitted its resignation to the country’s ruling military council.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The cabinet offered its resignation on Monday to Egypt’s transitional military rulers as security forces carried out an increasingly lethal crackdown on three days of violent street protests, reviving the uncertainty about Egypt’s future that marked the earliest days of the Arab Spring.

articles.headline: Credit Risks in Europe Push Stocks Downward
articles.snippet: Although the Congressional committee charged with planning deficit cuts is stalled, analysts said concerns about the euro zone had more effect on the markets.
articles.abstract: Although the Congressional committee charged with planning deficit cuts is stalled, analysts said concerns about the euro zone had more effect on the markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stock prices and bond yields declined on Wall Street on Monday, as credit risks in Europe overpowered any market concerns over the failure in Washington to reach a deficit reduction package.
